There are dozens of ways to make money in markets. MAs, Trendlines, Fibs, EW, swings, FA, trend, counter trend, long term or short term, any of it can work for those who are skilled, put time into their process and stay consistent with it.

Pure shorting has bad math, unless using puts, gain is capped at 100%, risk is technically unlimited until they close you out. Shorting has a time and place for very skilled traders, but for most people it adds more complication. One bad short trade can be game over.

My opinions are based on my own personal experience. I don't try to say what "works or doesn't work" or that one method is superior. Dozens of ways to make money in markets. Also, dozens of ways to lose money. I try to eliminate as many ways to lose money as I can.

When it starts to unwind, use good exits and down chase downtrends. For most people trading short offers more complication. Get consistently profitable on the long side first for a few years before trying to short as well.

You can be extremely profitable over time and not take one short side trade ever. I trade short selectively in confirmed down trends for my time frame. To ‚Äúsurvive‚Äù you need great money management, risk management and exit skills.

There are very few "perfect entries". The longer your time frame, the less it matters. You don't have to buy the dead low or sell the exact high to be extremely profitable. You also need to have a position to make money.

Recent volatility has made it tough for some to get into single stock positions for fear of the bottom falling out or perfect entry.  ETFs offer strong returns& avoid single stock event risk. Look at charts of $FDN $KWEB $SMH $BOTZ $ITA $EEM as an example.

If you have a 3 to 6 hour/day timeframe, then every penny might matter. If you have a 3 to 6 month or longer time frame, than position sizing and stop placement give the trade room to work. Any outcome from here is always possible.

You also need to realize that everyone on FinTwit has different experience levels, skill levels and time frames. Just because someone is doing something for a one week time horizon doesn't mean that's best for everyone.

If you follow some type of a price based - rules based process, then you know what gets you in and what gets you out. Taking emotions out of it as much as you can helps. Emotional money decisions are usually bad decisions.

Stocks have a few outcomes from here:  1. Buyable pullback over the next weeks or weeks, which having a plan will help you put money to work.  2. It all goes bad - which having a plan with pre-determined exits in place will get you out in one piece.

If you have a one week time horizon, no money management and no risk controls, the stock market is a tough place to learn.  Slightly longer time horizon, some discipline and a plan - there's alot of money to be made over time (longer than one week).

Here's the good news: Once you cut past the media hype and FinTwit noise... If you just started in markets this week and went all in, you're down a whopping 3.88%. If you've been in for a bit longer, you've made quite alot of real money.  Reality

If you don't blow yourself up due to overtrading, you stand a chance. Markets never blow people up, they blow themselves up. Small money thinks it can become big money by taking excess risk. For the most part, Big money got to be that way by managing risk.

$SPX over 90 years =9.8% Last few years much stronger. Most active fund managers under-perform the index over time. Many retail traders trying to earn that in a week or month. Unrealistic expectations = overtrading = big drawdowns = blow ups.

One reason most people blow up is because they over-trade.  They over-trade due to unrealistic return expectations. +15%y CAGR over years beats $SPX avg 9.8% handily (some years may be higher, some lower) many are trying to make that in a month/week That math doesn't work
If you develop  program that earns on average 3x in every winning trade over time and loses 1x in every losing trade, if you keep positions in check, and don't over trade, the math works.

EXPECTANCY (Trading Math )  The most important part of trade management that very few fully understand.  Profitable trading is much more about math and expectancy than it is about being "right or wrong".

Now change the numbers:  100 trades  35% Winners x  +$2,000 avg 65% losers    x  -$1,000 avg   +$70,000 - $65,000 Net =  +$5,000  *** Improve it a bit:  45% winners  x +$2,500 avg 55% losers     x -$1,000 avg  + $112,500 -   $55,000  Net = +$57,500  Expectancy.

Profitability is based on expectancy, not "just" win rate.  If a system has:   65% winners & you avg   +$1,000 per trade  35% losers    & you avg   - $2,000 per trade  how profitable is the system?  100 trades:  Winners  = + $65,000 Losers     =   ($70,000)  Net = ($5,000)

One of the best resources I know of on Expectancy, Money Management and "Trading Math".
If trading was easy, everyone would be successful. Fact is, it isn't. Takes time, study, discipline, self-analysis, and persistence.
Learning to hold winners & cut losers takes discipline & isn't easy. A rules based system helps, but that isn't easy either. None of it is
People are wired for instant gratification (selling winners fast) & delaying pain(holding losers). This is counter-intuitive to good trading
When entering a trade, set a stop & if the trade starts working, leave it alone. Small winners can't become huge winners if you cut them.
A 40% win rate system can be hugely profitable is average winners are significantly larger than average losers. Cut losers/push winners.
Win rate, touted by newsletter sellers, is secondary. A 90% win rate system can go broke if it takes very small wins & giant losers.
One of the most important concepts to grasp in trading is Money Management. Size of average losing trade vs size of average winning trade.
